content.description: Hard start, fun finish. Named after the best dog in the world, Nelly Cook. Start in the left facing slab and move into super fun moderate climbing with unique holds.
content.location: Left of Synchro 5.12d

content.description:
Climb through a crimpy start (crux) to an exposed traverse at the anchors.

 To avoid ridiculous rope drag, extend your quickdraws on bolt 3 (or better yet, use a 120cm sling). The easiest way to clean this route is to backlead.

 Temporary PG-13 Rating, Read comments for more information.
content.location: Directly to the right of Easy Tiger (The 5.7)

climbs.name: Synchronization of the Gyration aka Synchro

content.description: You have two options for the start: either pull a long gaston move from the right or start left on the arete. Climb up to a sloping ledge. Grab the best rest you can, and then fight up and left to a heartbreaker dead point move. Pull a hard reach over the roof and you've got it.
content.location: This route sits in-between Whoa Nelly 5.10b and Money Shot 5.11a; to identify Whoa Nelly, look for the anchors about midway up the wall. Synchro is the line to the right of it that pushes all the way through the roof.

content.description: Power Tech Face climbing
content.location: Far Left Stark Wall Start in Crack

content.description: really fun route with great movement.  Climb the flake up to a good rest before an underclinging crux protects the anchors
content.location: route starts just above the graffiti that reads 'SMOKE ICE,' just down hill from the stark wall and uphill of moneyshot.

content.description: Yell County full body pump.  Every move makes you think on this Classic!
content.location: left of anti-christ

content.description: Cool climbing to a cruxy section in Middle.
content.location: Start on block by the Pot 420 grafitti

content.description: Super, super classic 5.11a. Lots of funky moves, but tons of fun. Work straight up until you hit a dihedral and then start heading right towards the large hueco. Pull out the left side of this and then trend up right again through the crux to the anchors.
content.protection: One quickdraw for the first bolt, the rest have permadraws.
content.location: Second route with permadraws from the far right.

content.description: Starts on Magnum P.I. 5.12c, but finishes on Money Shot 5.11a. A little contrived overall, but it features some really cool climbing at parts; Start Magnum but move left at the second bolt onto an independent bolt line. Climb into the large hueco sit-down rest on Money, but don't head out left. Instead, stem out of the hueco and move back right onto the face before joining Â back onto Money Shot's line.
content.protection: 8 bolts and bolt anchors. A runner is recommended on the second bolt to prevent bad drag.
content.location: Shares the start of Magnum P.I. 5.12c (the rightmost line on the rock).

content.description: Dardanelle's right-most line; Start in a dihedral and fight up to the hueco where a kneebar rest awaits. After the rest endure technical moves to a heady lunge before the anchors.
content.location: It is the rightmost line of bolts at D-Rock. From the sign walk right about 20 feet until the bolts stop.

content.description:
Start left of the tree on the arete and climb onto the right face. First bolt is only there to protect you from decking before you can stand up on the ledge.

 The crux is either the start or directly before/after the 2nd bolt.
content.location: Directly to the left of Easy Tiger (The 7) on the left side of the face.

content.description: The easiest sport route at Dardanelle, and an okay warm up. Follow the first three bolts up the low-angle arete and then step left into the dihedral, where the climbing gets significantly easier. The chains are located on top of the wall at the top of the route, and a pain to reach for shorter climbers.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains with fixed draws.
content.location: Uphill from most of the routes, this one wanders up a low-angle slab. The bolts are easy to find, and start directly above a small cave. Step off of the boulder at the base to start.

content.description:
The start is a stand-start hand match on obvious chalked holds about 7ft high in the middle of the rock. This route is a traverse to the left most side without a "top out". The finish is about 5-6 ft below the top of the rock, with an obvious outlet to stand on. If you want to add to the difficulty a little bit, you can do a sit start below the aforementioned starting holds and it would easily enter into v2-3 territory. 

  The holds near the end of the problem tend to get a bit more chossy, so DO NOT rely on anything small. Be smart and have a good spotting team at the ready. 

  This problem was established with the combined effort of Jonathan Williams (FA), Spencer Maske, and myself. 

  Shoutout to Motown USA.
content.protection: Pads and Spotters. The more the better. The FA was done with 2 spotters and 1 pad, but we would suggest bringing as many pads as possible because it is a traverse with some pretty uneven terrain.
content.location: If you continue past Easy Tiger (The 7) 5.7 route you will eventually find a "path" that heads out to the left. There is a v4 that many locals know as Pistol Arrow that isn't yet posted on MP or in any guidebooks afaik. Continue past that and you will soon find Finger-Blaster, use pictures for aid.

content.description: The new designated "warm up" for Dardanelle Rock.
content.protection: 4 Bolts and anchors at the top.
content.location: Route is located on the trail to the top, just past the Stark Wall. You'll see the new water tower on the left.

content.description: This overhanging corner begins about 30 feet left of the two Denture Adventures.Â âIts steepness may be a bit intimidating for the beginner leader but, in all actuality, abundant big feet and perfect jams create a surprisingly moderate passage.
content.protection: Bolt anchor. SR, rack to a #4 Camalot
content.location: One of the left most routes at D-Rock, there are only two hangers bolted at the top of this blocky crack climb. I'll try to add a photo next time I'm there.

content.description: The Aid Route had no attention for years, We decided to free climb the beast. Hard 5.11 climbing to weird off Angle sloper dyno.
content.location: Far right on Stark Wall

content.description: Classic Dardanelle pump-fest. Wander up the face and finish with a scary mantel and a hard anchor clip.
content.location: Immediately left of Woah Nelly 5.10b; look Nelly's anchors in the middle of the wall, this route is the bolt line immediately to the left.

content.description: One star for adding an eliminate problem.. but stopped in and got bored. Same start hold on the beach bolder as the other. Go up and right the arete has a sloping crimp, grab and fire for the top lip, donât cheat the feet or going for the small right hand around in the dihedral. Foot rail in off use something else. Have fun. Come around the face after catching the lip.
content.location: Beach boulder, no right foot rail. No dihedral.

content.description: Bouldering problem on the beach. Sit start with some obvious chalked holds. Move around the arete to the left for the top out. Crux move is finding good hands near the top.
content.protection: Bouldering problem--you'll need a pad and a spotter!
content.location: From the parking area, head toward the beach. This problem is located on the first boulder to the left on the east facing side, far left hand side of the face.

content.description: Climb antichrist Then keep going to the top chains very bouldery. Was the first route redpointed on the Wall.
content.protection: All of Antichrist 5.11c has permadraws except for the first bolt. It protects the weird sequence to get off the ground. Once you start up Antichrist Superstar 5.13a, it also is covered in permas EXCEPT for the roof. Don't forget some quickdraws for the roof and the face out of the roof.

content.description: Another great route at Dardanelle- the book says it's beta-intensive, but I didn't think the sequence was really all that hard to figure out. It certainly is pumpy, though. Bomber rock, fun movement.
content.protection: 5 fixed draws. Lower off at the first set of chains.
content.location: From the parking area, take the trail past the sign and start heading uphill. Antichrist is the route that starts on a detached flake, heads up right to the first bolt which is located directly over a bulge.

content.description: Really fun climbing to the First Anchors (5.12b)to an in your face Crux at the 2nd Anchors
content.location: middle of wall

content.description:
D Rock is fairly different from most crags in the Natural State. It's located in Russellville, south of I-40. There aren't a whole lot of lines here, but most of the ones present are great. The crag is known for it's plethora of hard sport routes- almost everything is 5.11 or harder (with a ton of good 5.12s.) It's also unique in the way that almost every sport line has fixed draws. That and the graffiti and the <5 minute approach for almost all of the lines mean that this almost feels more like a gym than a true Arkansas crag. That being said, if you want hard sport, don't miss this area. 

  The rock is still sandstone, but it's a different feel than most of the stuff up in Newton County- it's harder and more angular. Also, it feels like the holds are always facing the wrong way, which makes climbing here much more interesting.
